close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection / request-parsing code that constructs the method string
explanation:
You must be able to prove that the const char *method argument passed to strcmp is a valid, NUL-terminated buffer (and non-NULL) whenever ahc_echo is invoked. For that the analyzer needs the following symbols and why:

- strcmp
  - To understand the exact behaviour of the string function being used (it scans both operands until a NUL is reached). This is the function governed by the MISRA rule; knowing its semantics is required to reason about possible out-of-bounds reads.

- MHD_AccessHandlerCallback (request handler prototype)
  - The typedef/prototype used by libmicrohttpd for the request handler exposes the contract for the method parameter (type, whether it may be NULL, lifetime assumptions). The MISRA check requires knowing whether the library guarantees a NUL-terminated C string is passed.

- MHD_start_daemon (or the specific libmicrohttpd function that registers the access handler)
  - The registration site shows how ahc_echo is installed and which internal library code will later call it. To prove safety you need to inspect the code-path that invokes the handler and supplies the method argument (i.e., whether the library provides a NUL-terminated method string).

- main (site that registers ahc_echo)
  - The local registration call in this program (commonly in main) is needed to find the exact registration parameters (which callback signature/flags were used) and trace into the library invocation contract for method.

- ahc_cb (other callback/wrapper in this codebase)
  - There is often a wrapper or other callbacks in this project that mediate between the library and application handlers; inspecting ahc_cb shows whether the wrapper transforms/forwards the method pointer or could pass an invalid/non-NUL buffer to ahc_echo.

- struct MHD_Connection / request-parsing code that constructs the method string
  - The actual code inside libmicrohttpd that parses the HTTP request line and creates the method buffer is the ultimate source of truth for whether method is NUL-terminated and valid for strcmp. You must inspect the request-parsing and connection code (or the relevant struct definitions) to ensure no partial buffers or non-terminated slices are passed.

With these symbols you can trace the origin and guarantees of the method pointer and determine whether the strcmp call in ahc_echo can cause an out-of-bounds read, satisfying the MISRA string-handling rule check.
